question: Compare the two photographs and say what might be difficult for the people in these situations.

default.text: Both photos show people working. In the first one, there's a meeting in an office with people sitting around a table. In the second photo, someone is working in a café. In both situations, people are trying to get work done.

alternatives.phrase: In both pictures we can see

default.text: But there are some big differences. The office looks really formal - everyone's in a proper meeting. But the café is much more relaxed and casual. Also, in the office they're working as a team, while in the café the person is on their own.

vocabulary.phrase: But there are some big differences

default.text: So what might be difficult? Well, in the office meeting, I think the hard part is probably dealing with different opinions. Everyone has their own ideas and you have to agree on something. Plus, you might feel nervous speaking in front of your colleagues. In the café, the main problem would be all the noise and people walking around. It's really hard to concentrate when there's so much going on. Also, you don't have anyone to help you if you get stuck.

vocabulary.phrase: I think the hard part is probably

alternative1.text: These two pictures both show people in working environments. The first picture shows an office meeting with several colleagues around a table. In the second one, someone is working alone in a café. What they have in common is that both people are focused on their work.

alternatives.phrase: In both pictures we can see

alternative1.text: However, they're quite different in several ways. While the office meeting looks formal and structured, the café is much more casual. Another difference is that the office workers are collaborating as a team, whereas the person in the café is working alone.

alternatives.phrase: But there are some big differences
On the other hand, these differ significantly

alternative1.text: As for what might be difficult, I'd say that in the office meeting, the challenge is probably managing different opinions. It could be stressful trying to get everyone to agree. Also, you might feel pressure speaking in front of colleagues. In the café, I think the main difficulty would be the distractions - there's noise, people moving around, and no privacy. Plus, if you get stuck on something, there's nobody there to help you.

vocabulary.phrase: As for what might be difficult

alternative2.text: In both pictures we can see people in work situations. The top photo shows a formal meeting in an office, while the bottom one shows someone working in a café. One thing these situations have in common is that in both cases, people are trying to complete work tasks.

vocabulary.phrase: In both pictures we can see
One thing these situations have in common

alternative2.text: On the other hand, there are significant differences. The office meeting appears quite formal and organized, whereas the café setting is considerably more relaxed. Another clear difference is that the first situation involves teamwork and collaboration, while the second shows independent work.

alternatives.phrase: But there are some big differences

alternative2.text: Regarding the difficulties, in my opinion, the office workers might find it challenging to manage conflicting ideas and reach agreement. There could also be pressure to perform well in front of their team. As for the café situation, I imagine the main problem would be staying focused with all the background noise and movement. It's likely that working alone means you can't ask for help when you need it.

alternatives.phrase: As for what might be difficult

question: Compare the two photographs and say how the people might be feeling in these situations.

default.text: Both photos show people in places with lots of other people around. The first one shows a busy city street at night with crowds everywhere. The second photo shows students working together in a library. In both situations, people are sharing the same space.

alternatives.phrase: In both photographs we can see

default.text: But the social situations are totally different. In the city, nobody really knows each other - it's just random people walking past. It's quite impersonal. But the students are clearly friends working together. They're talking and helping each other. The city is about being alone even though you're with people, but the library is about real connection.

vocabulary.phrase: But the social situations are totally different

alternatives.phrase: However, the social dynamics are very different
On the other hand, the quality of social interaction differs dramatically

default.text: How might people be feeling? In the busy city, I think it's mixed. Some people probably feel excited by all the lights and energy. But others might feel overwhelmed or even lonely even though there are so many people around. Everyone's just going somewhere and not really connecting. The students probably feel quite different - maybe a bit stressed about their work, but they also feel supported because they have friends there. Studying in a group makes you feel less alone when things are difficult.

alternatives.phrase: I'd say emotions are probably mixed
I imagine people might experience various emotions

alternative1.text: These two pictures both show people in shared spaces. The first depicts a crowded city street at night, while the second shows students collaborating in a library. What they have in common is that people are surrounded by others in both situations.

alternatives.phrase: In both photographs we can see

alternative1.text: However, the social dynamics are very different. While the urban setting involves strangers with no connection to each other, the library shows friends supporting one another. Another key difference is that the city feels anonymous and impersonal, whereas the study group represents genuine social bonds.

vocabulary.phrase: However, the social dynamics are very different

alternatives.phrase: But the social situations are totally different
On the other hand, the quality of social interaction differs dramatically

alternative1.text: As for how people might be feeling, I'd say in the city scene, emotions are probably mixed. Some individuals might feel energized by the vibrant atmosphere, while others could feel overwhelmed or isolated despite the crowds. In the study group, on the other hand, I imagine students feel a combination of academic stress and social support. The presence of friends probably makes the pressure more manageable.

vocabulary.phrase: As for how people might be feeling

alternative2.text: In both photographs we can see people in crowded environments. The first shows a busy urban street at night, while the second depicts students working together in a library. One thing both situations share is that individuals are physically close to other people.

vocabulary.phrase: In both photographs we can see

alternative2.text: On the other hand, the quality of social interaction differs dramatically. The city represents anonymous coexistence with strangers, whereas the library shows meaningful connection between friends. It seems to me that the urban scene is about isolation within crowds, while the study group is about genuine companionship.

alternatives.phrase: But the social situations are totally different
However, the social dynamics are very different

alternative2.text: Regarding their feelings, I imagine people in the city might experience various emotions. Some could feel excited by the urban energy and lights, while others might feel lonely or anxious despite being surrounded by people. As for the students, I reckon they're probably feeling academic pressure, but the support of their friends helps. It's likely that working together makes the stress more bearable. What's more, having company during difficult tasks probably reduces feelings of isolation.

alternatives.phrase: As for how people might be feeling
In the study group, on the other hand

question: Compare the two photographs and say why the people might have chosen to spend their time in these ways.

default.text: Both photos show people having fun and relaxing. In the first one, people are watching a movie at the cinema. In the second picture, a family is playing board games at home. In both cases, people are choosing entertainment to enjoy their free time.

alternatives.phrase: In both photographs we can see

default.text: But they're quite different types of entertainment. The cinema is a public place where you watch something that's been made for you. You're passive - you just sit and watch. Board games at home are totally different - you're active and you have to think and make decisions. Also, at the cinema you're with strangers, while board games are usually with family or close friends.

alternatives.phrase: However, the forms of entertainment are quite different
On the other hand, these are very different forms of recreation

default.text: So why might they have chosen these? I think people go to the cinema because they want to escape into a story and forget about their own lives for a couple of hours. The big screen and sound system make it really immersive. It's a special experience you can't get at home. The family playing board games probably chose this because they wanted to spend quality time together. Board games make you interact and talk with each other. Plus it's much cheaper than going out, and you can pause whenever you want.

alternative1.text: These two pictures both show people enjoying leisure activities. The first shows cinema-goers watching a film, while the second depicts a family playing board games at home. What these activities have in common is that people are using their free time for entertainment.

alternatives.phrase: In both photographs we can see

vocabulary.phrase: What these activities have in common

alternatives.phrase: One thing both situations have in common

alternative1.text: However, the forms of entertainment are quite different. While going to the cinema is a passive experience in a public venue, board gaming is active and interactive in a private setting. Another difference is that cinemas involve strangers sharing an experience, whereas board games typically involve close family or friends.

vocabulary.phrase: However, the forms of entertainment are quite different

alternatives.phrase: On the other hand, these are very different forms of recreation

alternative1.text: As for why they chose these activities, I'd say cinema-goers probably want to escape reality through immersive storytelling. Perhaps they enjoy the experience of a big screen and surround sound that you can't replicate at home. The family with board games, on the other hand, likely prioritized spending quality time together. I imagine they wanted an activity that encourages conversation and interaction. Plus, it's more economical and flexible than going out.

alternatives.phrase: So why might they have chosen these?

alternative2.text: In both photographs we can see people engaged in recreational activities. The first shows people at a cinema watching a movie, while the second depicts a family playing board games at home. One thing both situations have in common is that people are seeking entertainment during their leisure time.

vocabulary.phrase: In both photographs we can see
One thing both situations have in common

alternatives.phrase: What these activities have in common

alternative2.text: On the other hand, these are very different forms of recreation. Cinema involves passive consumption of media in a public commercial space, whereas board gaming requires active participation in a domestic setting. It seems to me that the social aspect also differs - cinemas involve anonymous crowds, while board games involve intimate family interaction.

alternatives.phrase: However, the forms of entertainment are quite different

alternative2.text: Regarding their motivations, I imagine cinema-goers are seeking escapism through high-quality visual storytelling. They might appreciate the immersive experience that only a theater can provide. As for the family playing board games, I reckon they wanted to strengthen family bonds through shared activity. It's possible they value face-to-face interaction over digital entertainment. What's more, board games offer flexibility and value for money compared to commercial entertainment.

alternatives.phrase: So why might they have chosen these?
The family with board games, on the other hand

question: Compare the two photographs and say what might be enjoyable or frustrating about shopping in these places.

default.text: Both photos show places where people go shopping. The first one is a big modern shopping mall with lots of stores. The second picture shows a local market with individual stalls. In both situations, people are buying things they need or want.

alternatives.phrase: In both photographs we can see

default.text: But the shopping experiences are completely different. The mall is modern, clean, and organized with big chain stores. Everything has a fixed price and you can use your card. The market is much more traditional and authentic. It looks a bit messy and chaotic, with fresh produce and small vendors. You probably need cash and might have to bargain over prices.

vocabulary.phrase: But the shopping experiences are completely different

alternatives.phrase: However, the shopping experiences are very different
On the other hand, these retail environments differ significantly

default.text: What might be enjoyable or frustrating? In the mall, the good thing is it's convenient - everything's in one place, it's air-conditioned, and it's easy to find what you want. But it can feel impersonal and crowded, plus everything is quite expensive. At the market, the enjoyable part is the atmosphere - it's lively and you get fresh, local products. You can talk to the vendors and get a better deal. But it might be frustrating if it's too hot, crowded, or if you don't speak the language well enough to negotiate.

alternative1.text: These two pictures both show shopping environments. The first depicts a modern shopping mall with multiple stores, while the second shows a traditional outdoor market. What they have in common is that both are places where consumers purchase goods.

alternatives.phrase: In both photographs we can see
One thing both places have in common

alternative1.text: However, the shopping experiences are very different. While the mall is modern and climate-controlled with chain retailers, the market is traditional and open-air with independent vendors. Another difference is that malls have fixed prices, whereas markets often involve price negotiation.

vocabulary.phrase: However, the shopping experiences are very different

alternatives.phrase: But the shopping experiences are completely different
On the other hand, these retail environments differ significantly

alternative1.text: As for what's enjoyable or frustrating, I'd say the mall offers convenience - everything in one location, comfortable climate, and easy transactions. However, it could feel impersonal and prices tend to be higher. The market, on the other hand, provides atmosphere and cultural experience. You might enjoy the fresh products and bargaining opportunities. Perhaps the frustrations would be the heat, crowds, or language barriers when negotiating prices.

vocabulary.phrase: As for what's enjoyable or frustrating

alternatives.phrase: What might be enjoyable or frustrating?
Regarding what might be enjoyable or frustrating

alternative2.text: In both photographs we can see retail environments where shopping takes place. The first shows a contemporary shopping center, while the second depicts a traditional market setting. One thing both places have in common is that they serve as commercial spaces for buying and selling goods.

vocabulary.phrase: In both photographs we can see
One thing both places have in common

alternative2.text: On the other hand, these retail environments differ significantly. The mall represents organized, standardized shopping, whereas the market embodies traditional, informal commerce. It seems to me that another key difference is pricing - malls use fixed prices, while markets typically involve negotiation.

alternatives.phrase: But the shopping experiences are completely different
However, the shopping experiences are very different

alternative2.text: Regarding what might be enjoyable or frustrating, I imagine mall shoppers appreciate the convenience and comfort - centralized location, air conditioning, and straightforward purchasing. They might find it frustrating that it feels somewhat impersonal and prices are generally higher. As for the market, I reckon the enjoyable aspects would be the vibrant atmosphere and fresh, local products. It's possible that bargaining adds to the experience. What could be frustrating, though, is dealing with heat, navigating crowds, or struggling with language barriers during negotiations.

alternatives.phrase: What might be enjoyable or frustrating?
As for what's enjoyable or frustrating
The market, on the other hand

question: Compare the two photographs and say why the people might have decided to spend their time in these ways.

default.text: Both photos show people enjoying nature. The first picture is of a beautiful beach, and the second one shows someone hiking in the mountains. In both cases, people have chosen to spend time outside in really nice places.

alternatives.phrase: In both photographs we can see

default.text: But they're very different activities. The beach is all about relaxing - you just sit there and chill out. The mountain hiking is completely different - it's active and you need to be quite fit. The beach is easy to get to, but going up a mountain needs proper planning.

alternatives.phrase: However, the activities are quite different
On the other hand, these are very different

default.text: So why did they choose these activities? I think the people at the beach probably wanted to escape from their busy lives and just relax. Maybe they were feeling stressed and needed somewhere quiet and peaceful. The mountain hiker is different - they probably chose this because they like a challenge. Some people prefer doing something active where they push themselves. Plus, the views from the top of a mountain are amazing - that's a pretty good reason to climb up there!

alternative1.text: These images both show people enjoying outdoor activities. The first one depicts a peaceful beach setting, while the second shows someone hiking in the mountains. What they have in common is that both individuals have chosen to spend time in natural environments.

alternatives.phrase: In both photographs we can see

alternative1.text: However, the activities are quite different. While the beach experience is all about relaxation and unwinding, mountain hiking is much more active and challenging. Another difference is that beaches are usually easy to access, whereas mountain trips require more preparation.

vocabulary.phrase: However, the activities are quite different

alternatives.phrase: On the other hand, these are very different

alternative1.text: As for why they chose these activities, I'd say the beach-goers probably wanted to de-stress and escape from their daily routine. Perhaps they needed some peace and quiet away from their busy lives. The mountain hiker, on the other hand, likely chose this activity for the physical challenge. Some people enjoy pushing their limits and testing themselves. Plus, the amazing views from the top could be a big motivation.

alternative2.text: In both photographs we can see people spending time in nature. The first shows a stunning beach scene, while the second depicts a mountain hiking adventure. One thing both situations have in common is that people have decided to get outdoors and away from urban life.

vocabulary.phrase: In both photographs we can see
One thing both situations have in common

alternative2.text: On the other hand, these are very different ways to spend free time. The beach represents passive relaxation and rest, whereas hiking involves physical activity and endurance. It seems to me that accessibility is another key difference - beaches are generally straightforward to reach, while mountain expeditions need careful planning.

alternatives.phrase: However, the activities are quite different

alternative2.text: Regarding their motivations, I imagine the people at the beach were looking for a way to relax and escape stress. They might have been feeling overwhelmed and needed somewhere calm and peaceful. As for the hiker, I reckon they chose this activity because they enjoy physical challenges. It's possible that they're the type of person who likes pushing themselves. What's more, the spectacular views you get from mountain peaks could be a major reason for making the effort.

alternatives.phrase: The hiker, on the other hand

question: Compare the two photographs and say what the people might be learning from these experiences.

default.text: Both pictures show people learning something, but in different ways. In the first photo, there are university students studying together in a library. In the second one, there's a parent at home with young children using a tablet. They're all focused on learning.

alternatives.phrase: In both photographs we can see

default.text: The big difference is what kind of learning it is. The students are doing serious study - probably for exams or assignments. It's formal and organized. But the children at home are learning through games and fun activities. It's much more relaxed. Also, the students work together as a group, but the little kids need their parent to help them.

alternatives.phrase: However, the type of learning is quite different
On the other hand, the learning contexts are very different

default.text: So what are they learning? The university students are obviously learning their subjects - history, science, whatever they're studying. But they're also learning how to work with other people and how to manage their time. The young children are probably learning basic things like numbers, colors, or new words. They're also learning important skills like how to pay attention and follow instructions. And spending time with their parent teaches them they're loved and safe.

alternative1.text: These two pictures both show learning situations. The first shows university students working together in a library. In the second, a parent is helping young children learn using a tablet at home. What these situations have in common is that learning is taking place in both.

alternatives.phrase: In both photographs we can see

vocabulary.phrase: What these situations have in common

alternative1.text: However, the type of learning is quite different. While the students are engaged in formal academic study, the children are learning through play-based activities. Another difference is that the university students work independently as a group, whereas the young children require parental guidance.

vocabulary.phrase: However, the type of learning is quite different

alternatives.phrase: On the other hand, the learning contexts are very different

alternative1.text: As for what they're learning, I'd say the students are obviously developing knowledge in their academic subjects. Beyond that, they're probably learning collaboration skills and time management. The young children, on the other hand, are likely learning fundamental things like counting, colors, or vocabulary. Perhaps more importantly, they're also developing concentration skills and learning to follow instructions. Plus, the quality time with their parent helps them feel secure.

alternative2.text: In both photographs we can see educational activities taking place. The top picture shows students studying together in a library, while the bottom one shows a parent teaching young children at home with a tablet. One thing they share is that everyone is focused on acquiring new knowledge or skills.

vocabulary.phrase: In both photographs we can see

alternatives.phrase: What these situations have in common

alternative2.text: On the other hand, the learning contexts are very different. The university setting involves formal, structured study, whereas the home environment is more informal and playful. It seems to me that another key difference is independence - the students are working autonomously, while the children need adult support.

alternatives.phrase: However, the type of learning is quite different

alternative2.text: Regarding what they're learning, I imagine the university students are building subject knowledge in their chosen fields. They might also be developing important skills like teamwork and self-discipline. As for the young children, I reckon they're learning basic concepts - numbers, letters, and vocabulary. It's likely that they're also developing cognitive skills like concentration and following instructions. What's more, the interaction with their parent is probably teaching them about trust and security.

alternatives.phrase: The children, on the other hand

question: Compare the two photographs and say what skills the people might be developing through these activities.

default.text: Both photos show people doing sports and getting exercise. In the first one, there's a team playing football together on a field. In the second picture, someone is working out alone in a gym. In both situations, people are being active and trying to stay fit.

alternatives.phrase: In both photographs we can see

default.text: But the activities are really different. Football is all about teamwork - you have to pass the ball and work together. You're depending on other people. But in the gym, you're completely on your own. You choose your exercises and go at your own pace. Also, football is outside with fresh air, while the gym is indoors.

vocabulary.phrase: But the activities are really different

alternatives.phrase: However, these are quite different activities
On the other hand, the nature of these activities differs significantly

default.text: What skills might they be developing? The football players are obviously getting fitter and stronger. But they're also learning to communicate and cooperate with teammates. You have to trust other people and think quickly. The person in the gym is probably building physical strength and stamina. But they're also learning discipline - you need to push yourself when there's nobody else there to motivate you. Plus, they're learning to set personal goals and work towards them.

vocabulary.phrase: What skills might they be developing?

alternatives.phrase: As for the skills they're developing

alternative1.text: These two pictures both show people engaging in physical activity. The first depicts a team sport - football - while the second shows someone training individually at a gym. What they have in common is that both involve exercise and physical fitness.

alternatives.phrase: In both photographs we can see

alternative1.text: However, these are quite different activities. While football requires cooperation and teamwork, gym training is a solitary pursuit. Another difference is that team sports involve coordination with others, whereas individual training allows complete personal control over pace and intensity.

vocabulary.phrase: However, these are quite different activities

alternatives.phrase: But the activities are really different
On the other hand, the nature of these activities differs significantly

alternative1.text: As for the skills they're developing, I'd say the football players are certainly improving their fitness and stamina. Beyond that, they're learning valuable social skills - communication, teamwork, and trust. The gym-goer, on the other hand, is probably developing physical strength and endurance. Perhaps more importantly, they're building self-discipline and learning to stay motivated without external pressure. Plus, they're developing goal-setting abilities.

vocabulary.phrase: As for the skills they're developing

alternatives.phrase: What skills might they be developing?

alternative2.text: In both photographs we can see people participating in physical exercise. The first shows a team sport environment with football players, while the second depicts solitary gym training. One thing both activities share is their focus on physical development and fitness.

vocabulary.phrase: In both photographs we can see

alternative2.text: On the other hand, the nature of these activities differs significantly. Team football emphasizes collective effort and interdependence, whereas gym training centers on individual achievement. It seems to me that another key difference is the social dynamic - football fosters interpersonal skills, while gym training cultivates self-reliance.

However, these are quite different activities

alternative2.text: Regarding the skills being developed, I imagine the football players are enhancing their cardiovascular fitness and coordination. They might also be cultivating essential teamwork abilities - communication, collaboration, and strategic thinking. As for the individual trainer, I reckon they're building muscular strength and physical endurance. It's likely that they're also developing intrinsic motivation and self-accountability. The gym-goer, on the other hand

question: Compare the two photographs and say what might make these travel experiences memorable for the people.

default.text: Both photos show people traveling and exploring new places. In the first one, tourists are visiting famous buildings and landmarks in a city. In the second picture, someone is on an adventure in nature, maybe by a lake or in the mountains. In both cases, people have left home to experience something different.

alternatives.phrase: In both photographs we can see

default.text: But they're totally different types of travel. The city trip is about culture and history - seeing museums, buildings, and learning about the place. There are lots of other tourists around. The nature adventure is the opposite - it's quiet and peaceful, with hardly anyone else there. You're surrounded by natural beauty instead of buildings.

alternatives.phrase: However, these are very different experiences
On the other hand, these represent contrasting travel philosophies

default.text: What might make these memorable? For the city tourists, I think it's all the famous sights they'll see - they can take photos with iconic buildings and share them with friends. They're experiencing different food and culture too. Every corner probably has something interesting. The nature adventurer will remember it differently - maybe it's the incredible sunrise over the water, or the complete silence and peace. Being away from crowds and technology makes you feel really connected to nature. Both are memorable but for totally different reasons.

alternative1.text: These two pictures both show people on travel experiences. The first depicts urban tourism with visitors exploring a historic city, while the second shows someone enjoying a natural wilderness setting. What these experiences have in common is that people are seeking new environments and memorable moments.

alternatives.phrase: In both photographs we can see

vocabulary.phrase: What these experiences have in common

alternative1.text: However, these are very different travel experiences. While city tourism focuses on cultural immersion and historical sites, nature adventures emphasize tranquility and natural beauty. Another difference is that urban travel involves crowds and constant stimulation, whereas wilderness exploration offers solitude and reflection.

alternatives.phrase: On the other hand, these represent contrasting travel philosophies

alternative1.text: As for what makes these memorable, I'd say the city tourists will remember the iconic landmarks and cultural discoveries. Perhaps they'll treasure the photographs with famous architecture and the taste of authentic local cuisine. The nature adventurer, on the other hand, might remember the breathtaking vistas and sense of peace. I imagine the absence of crowds and the connection with the natural world creates lasting impressions. Both experiences offer memorable moments, just through completely different means.

vocabulary.phrase: As for what makes these memorable

alternatives.phrase: Regarding what makes these experiences memorable

alternative2.text: In both photographs we can see people engaged in travel experiences. The first shows tourists in an urban cultural setting, while the second depicts a traveler in a pristine natural environment. One thing both experiences share is the pursuit of memorable encounters outside one's ordinary routine.

vocabulary.phrase: In both photographs we can see

alternatives.phrase: What these experiences have in common

alternative2.text: On the other hand, these represent contrasting travel philosophies. City tourism embodies cultural enrichment through architecture and heritage, whereas wilderness travel emphasizes communion with nature. It seems to me that another fundamental difference lies in the social dimension - urban tourism involves shared public spaces, while nature adventures provide intimate solitude.

Regarding what makes these experiences memorable, I imagine the urban tourists will cherish encounters with iconic monuments and immersion in unfamiliar cultures. They might particularly value the photographic documentation of famous landmarks and the opportunity to sample authentic regional cuisine. As for the nature adventurer, I reckon the memorable elements would be dramatic natural panoramas and profound tranquility. It's likely that the complete detachment from urban life and technology creates a deep sense of connection with the environment. What's more, both experiences offer transformative memories, though through fundamentally different sensory and emotional pathways.

alternatives.phrase: As for what makes these memorable
The nature adventurer, on the other hand
